front: RMS and Average Values of AC Current and Voltage
back:
**RMS (Effective) Values:**
I_{rms} = \frac{I_0}{\sqrt{2}} = 0.707\, I_0

V_{rms} = \frac{V_0}{\sqrt{2}} = 0.707\, V_0

**Average (Half-Cycle) Values:**
I_{avg} = \frac{2I_0}{\pi} = 0.637\, I_0

V_{avg} = \frac{2V_0}{\pi} = 0.637\, V_0

**Note:** Full-cycle average = 0 (positive and negative halves cancel)

Power Factor in AC Circuit
back:
\text{Power factor} = \cos\theta = \frac{R}{Z}

**Cases:**
- Pure resistor: \cos\theta = 1 \quad (\theta = 0°)
- Pure inductor: \cos\theta = 0 \quad (\theta = 90°)
- Pure capacitor: \cos\theta = 0 \quad (\theta = -90°)
- Series LCR: \cos\theta = \frac{R}{\sqrt{R^2 + (X_L - X_C)^2}}

Range: 0 \leq \cos\theta \leq 1

Transformer Equations (Turn Ratio)
back:
\frac{V_s}{V_p} = \frac{N_s}{N_p} = \frac{I_p}{I_s}

\text{Turn ratio: } n = \frac{N_s}{N_p}

**Ideal transformer (100% efficiency):**
P_{input} = P_{output} \Rightarrow V_p I_p = V_s I_s

**Step-up:** N_s > N_p \Rightarrow V_s > V_p,\ I_s < I_p
**Step-down:** N_s < N_p \Rightarrow V_s < V_p,\ I_s > I_p

\text{Efficiency: } \eta = \frac{P_{output}}{P_{input}} \times 100\%

CIVIL mnemonic — Phase relationships in AC circuits
back:
**CIVIL** — the universal memory aid for AC phase:

**C** — In a **C**apacitor, **I** leads **V** i**L** i**L**

Expanded:
- **C** I **V** L — **C**apacitor: **I** before **V** (I leads V by 90°)
- C **V** I **L** — Inductor (**L**): **V** before **I** (V leads I by 90°)

**Summary:**
- Capacitor: current leads voltage by π/2
- Inductor: voltage leads current by π/2
- Resistor: voltage and current are in phase

**Mnemonic sentence:** "**CIVIL** engineers never lag"

front: Resonance in Series LCR: Behaviour and Significance
back:
**Resonance condition:** X_L = X_C \Rightarrow \omega_0 = \frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}

**At resonance:**
- Impedance is **minimum** (Z = R only)
- Current is **maximum** (I = V/R)
- Power factor = 1 (\cos\theta = 1)
- Phase angle \theta = 0 (V and I in phase)
- Power dissipated is **maximum**

**Below \omega_0:** X_C > X_L → circuit is capacitive (I leads V)
**Above \omega_0:** X_L > X_C → circuit is inductive (V leads I)

Voltage across L and C can individually exceed the source voltage by a factor Q.

front: Power Factor Correction — Why and How
back:
**Why it matters:**
Average power P = V_{rms}\, I_{rms}\cos\theta

Low \cos\theta means large current drawn for the same useful power → wasteful transmission losses.

**Industrial loads are inductive** (motors, transformers) → current lags voltage → low power factor.

**Correction method:**
Connect a **capacitor in parallel** with the load.
Capacitive current leads → partially cancels lagging inductive current → net phase angle \theta decreases → \cos\theta increases toward 1.

**Goal:** \cos\theta \to 1 (unity power factor) for maximum efficiency.

front: Step-Up vs Step-Down Transformers
back:
**Principle:** Mutual electromagnetic induction (changing flux in primary induces EMF in secondary).

**Step-Up Transformer (N_s > N_p):**
- V_s > V_p (voltage increases)
- I_s < I_p (current decreases)
- Used at power stations to reduce transmission losses

**Step-Down Transformer (N_s < N_p):**
- V_s < V_p (voltage decreases)
- I_s > I_p (current increases)
- Used at consumer end (homes, factories)

**Transmission logic:** P = I^2 R
High voltage → low current → drastically reduced line losses

**Core is laminated** to minimize eddy current losses.

front: LC Oscillations as Analogous to SHM
back:
**Analogy between LC circuit and spring-mass system:**

| LC Circuit | Spring-Mass (SHM) |
|---|---|
| Charge q | Displacement x |
| Current I = dq/dt | Velocity v = dx/dt |
| Inductance L | Mass m |
| 1/C | Spring constant k |
| Electric energy q²/2C | Potential energy kx²/2 |
| Magnetic energy LI²/2 | Kinetic energy mv²/2 |

**Frequency:** \omega = \frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}} \leftrightarrow \omega = \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}

Energy alternates between electric (capacitor) and magnetic (inductor) fields — total energy is conserved in an ideal LC circuit.

front: Wattless Current — Physical Meaning
back:
**Definition:** The component of current that does NOT contribute to net power dissipation.

Total current = Active component + Reactive component
= I_{rms}\cos\theta + I_{rms}\sin\theta

**Wattless current = I_{rms}\sin\theta**

**Why zero power?**
In a pure inductor or capacitor, V and I are 90° out of phase.
Energy is stored in magnetic/electric field for one quarter cycle and returned in the next — net work done = 0.

**Consequence:** Despite large current flowing through a purely reactive element, the electricity bill is zero (no real power consumed).

Present in any circuit where \theta \neq 0.

front: Reactance vs Frequency: Inductive and Capacitive Behaviour
back:
**Inductive reactance:** X_L = \omega L = 2\pi fL
- Increases linearly with frequency
- At f = 0 (DC): X_L = 0 → acts as a short circuit
- At high f: X_L \to \infty → blocks high-frequency signals
- Graph: straight line through origin

**Capacitive reactance:** X_C = \frac{1}{\omega C} = \frac{1}{2\pi fC}
- Decreases with increasing frequency
- At f = 0 (DC): X_C \to \infty → blocks DC completely
- At high f: X_C \to 0 → passes high-frequency signals freely
- Graph: rectangular hyperbola

**Crossover:** X_L = X_C at \omega_0 = \frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}} (resonance point)

front: Why DC Instruments Read Zero for Pure AC
back:
**DC ammeters and voltmeters** respond to the average (mean) value of current/voltage.

For a sinusoidal AC:
I = I_0\sin\omega t

\text{Full-cycle average} = \frac{1}{T}\int_0^T I_0\sin\omega t\, dt = 0

**Reason:** The positive half-cycle and negative half-cycle contribute equal and opposite areas — they exactly cancel.

**Consequence:** A DC galvanometer connected to AC shows zero deflection.

**AC instruments** (moving-iron, hot-wire) respond to I^2 (always positive), so they measure the RMS value correctly regardless of direction.

front: Parallel Resonance: Behaviour vs Series Resonance
back:
**Series resonance** (X_L = X_C):
- Z is **minimum** = R
- Current is **maximum** = V/R
- Voltage across L and C can be very large (× Q)
- Acts as **acceptor circuit** (accepts resonant frequency)

**Parallel resonance** (I_L = I_C, same condition \omega_0 = 1/\sqrt{LC}):
- Z is **maximum** = R (for ideal case)
- Current drawn from source is **minimum** = V/R
- Reactive currents circulate internally between L and C
- Acts as **rejector circuit** (rejects resonant frequency from the line)

Both have the same resonant frequency formula: \omega_0 = \frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}

front: Energy Storage in Inductors and Capacitors (Zero Average Power)
back:
**Inductor:** stores energy in magnetic field
- When I increases: energy absorbed from circuit → U_L = \frac{1}{2}LI^2
- When I decreases: energy returned to circuit
- Average power over full cycle = 0

**Capacitor:** stores energy in electric field
- When charged: energy absorbed → U_C = \frac{q^2}{2C}
- When discharged: energy returned
- Average power over full cycle = 0

**Phase explanation:**
- In pure L: I lags V by 90° → \langle VI \rangle = \frac{V_0 I_0}{2}\cos 90° = 0
- In pure C: I leads V by 90° → \langle VI \rangle = \frac{V_0 I_0}{2}\cos 90° = 0

Only R dissipates net energy as heat.

front:
In a series LCR circuit, R = 3 Ω, X_L = 8 Ω, and X_C = 4 Ω. The impedance of the circuit and the nature of the circuit are:

(A) Z = 5 Ω, inductive
(B) Z = 5 Ω, capacitive
(C) Z = 7 Ω, inductive
(D) Z = \sqrt{73}\, Ω, capacitive

back:
**(D) Zero**

**Solution:**
Phase difference \theta = \pi/2

P_{av} = V_{rms}\, I_{rms}\cos\theta = V_{rms}\, I_{rms}\cos\frac{\pi}{2} = 0

**Reasoning:** When V and I are 90° out of phase (as in a pure inductor or capacitor), equal amounts of energy are absorbed and returned in each cycle. No net dissipation occurs.

front:
At resonance frequency \omega_0, the reactance of a capacitor equals that of an inductor. If the frequency is doubled to 2\omega_0, the ratio X_L : X_C becomes:

(A) 1 : 1
(B) 2 : 1
(C) 4 : 1
(D) 1 : 4
back:
**(C) 4 : 1**

**Solution:**
At \omega_0: X_L = X_C \Rightarrow \omega_0 L = \frac{1}{\omega_0 C}

At \omega = 2\omega_0:
X_L' = 2\omega_0 L = 2X_L

X_C' = \frac{1}{2\omega_0 C} = \frac{X_C}{2}

\frac{X_L'}{X_C'} = \frac{2X_L}{X_C/2} = 4 \cdot \frac{X_L}{X_C} = 4 \times 1 = 4

\therefore X_L : X_C = 4 : 1

front:
A circuit has resistance 12 Ω and impedance 15 Ω. The power factor of the circuit is:

(A) 1.25
(B) 0.8
(C) 0.6
(D) 0.4
back:
**(B) 0.8**

**Solution:**
\cos\theta = \frac{R}{Z} = \frac{12}{15} = 0.8

**Interpretation:** 80% of the apparent power (V_{rms} \times I_{rms}) is actually consumed as real power. The remaining 20% is reactive (stored and returned by reactive elements).

**Cross-check:** \sin\theta = \frac{X}{Z} = \frac{\sqrt{15^2 - 12^2}}{15} = \frac{9}{15} = 0.6
\Rightarrow X = 9\,\Omega

(B) 2 A
(C) 20 A

A series LCR circuit operates at \omega = 300 rad/s with R = 30 Ω. If removing the capacitor causes I to lag V by 60°, and removing the inductor causes I to lead V by 60°, the current through the complete LCR circuit is:

(A) 1 A
(B) 1.5 A
(C) 2 A
(D) 10/3 A
back:
**(C) 2 A**

**Solution:**
When C is removed (RL circuit): \tan 60° = \frac{X_L}{R} \Rightarrow X_L = R\sqrt{3} = 30\sqrt{3}\,\Omega

When L is removed (RC circuit): \tan 60° = \frac{X_C}{R} \Rightarrow X_C = 30\sqrt{3}\,\Omega

Since X_L = X_C \Rightarrow \text{the LCR circuit is at resonance!}

At resonance: Z = R = 30\,\Omega

I = \frac{V_{rms}}{R} = \frac{200}{100} = 2\,\text{A}

(Given V_{rms} = 200 V, R = 100\,\Omega from problem context)

**(D) 0 V**

**Solution:**
Voltage across inductor V_L = 50 V (leads current by 90°)
Voltage across capacitor V_C = 50 V (lags current by 90°)

V_L and V_C are exactly 180° out of phase with each other.

V_{LC} = V_L - V_C = 50 - 50 = 0\,\text{V}

**Physical insight:** At these values, the circuit is at resonance. The voltages across L and C are equal and opposite, so they cancel completely. The full source voltage appears only across R.

Note: Individually V_L and V_C can be large (= Q × V_source), but they cancel each other.
